pull_request.title: Paywall: "Log in" Link – Improve the experience for WPCOM users
pull_request.body:
## Proposed changes:
<!--- Explain what functional changes your PR includes -->
Improves the experience for WPCOM Users accessing subscriptions.

* Paywall "Log in" link – use the Magic Link flow instead of the "code flow" .
* User is not authenticated but logged in to wpcom – authenticate the user instead of going through the code flow. 
* User is not authenticated and not logged in to wpcom – send the user to the magic link flow instead of the code flow.

Next steps:
* Add site context to the login screen.
* Add site context to emails.
* User is not authenticated and not logged in to wpcom – Using a similar iframe as the "code flow" one, request a login link from the iframe without leaving the site to keep more context.
 
### Other information:

- [ ] Have you written new tests for your changes, if applicable?
- [ ] Have you checked the E2E test CI results, and verified that your changes do not break them?
- [ ] Have you tested your changes on WordPress.com, if applicable (if so, you'll see a generated comment below with a script to run)?

## Jetpack product discussion
<!-- If you're an Automattician, include a shortlink to the p2 discussion with Jetpack Product here. -->
<!-- Make sure any changes to existing products have been discussed and agreed upon -->

## Does this pull request change what data or activity we track or use?
<!--- If so, please add the "[Status] Needs Privacy Updates" label and explain what changes there are. -->
<!--- Check existing Jetpack support documents for a preview of the information we need. -->

## Testing instructions:
<!-- If you were reviewing this PR, how would you like the instructions to be presented? -->
<!-- Please include detailed testing steps, explaining how to test your change. -->
<!-- Bear in mind that context you working on is not obvious for everyone.  -->
<!-- Adding "simple" configuration steps will help reviewers to get to your PR as quickly as possible. -->
<!-- "Before / After" screenshots can also be very helpful when the change is visual. -->

Create a subscriber-only post in the following types of sites:

- Custom domain site
- Atomic site
- Jetpack site

Testing Scenarios:

- As a logged-in subscriber, test the link on all types of sites.
- As a logged-out subscriber, test the link on all types of sites.

pull_request.title: admin-ui: Register Akismet menu for Jetpack-the-plugin too
pull_request.body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->
<!-- Would you like this feature to be tested by Beta testers?
Please add testing instructions to projects/plugins/jetpack/to-test.md in a new commit as part of your PR. -->
<!-- a12s: If you have an expected version that you're aiming for the PR to add, please use the Milestone field to communicate it. If you leave it blank, that indicates there isn't a preference. -->


## Proposed changes:
<!--- Explain what functional changes your PR includes -->
In #32911, we changed Jetpack to try to start using Admin_Menu to register a menu for Akismet instead of doing it itself, to avoid a bug where we'd get duplicate menu entries if a standalone plugin initialized Admin_Menu before Jetpack got loaded.

Unfortunately it wasn't noticed that Admin_Menu specifically avoids registering a menu for Akismet if Jetpack is present, so now Akismet isn't being registered at all.

Fix that by removing that check, allowing Admin_Menu to register Akismet for Jetpack too.

### Other information:

- [ ] Have you written new tests for your changes, if applicable?
- [ ] Have you checked the E2E test CI results, and verified that your changes do not break them?
- [ ] Have you tested your changes on WordPress.com, if applicable (if so, you'll see a generated comment below with a script to run)?

## Jetpack product discussion
<!-- If you're an Automattician, include a shortlink to the p2 discussion with Jetpack Product here. -->
<!-- Make sure any changes to existing products have been discussed and agreed upon -->
https://github.com/Automattic/jetpack/issues/33550#issuecomment-1757583709
Fixes #33550

## Does this pull request change what data or activity we track or use?
<!--- If so, please add the "[Status] Needs Privacy Updates" label and explain what changes there are. -->
<!--- Check existing Jetpack support documents for a preview of the information we need. -->
No

## Testing instructions:
<!-- If you were reviewing this PR, how would you like the instructions to be presented? -->
<!-- Please include detailed testing steps, explaining how to test your change. -->
<!-- Bear in mind that context you working on is not obvious for everyone.  -->
<!-- Adding "simple" configuration steps will help reviewers to get to your PR as quickly as possible. -->
<!-- "Before / After" screenshots can also be very helpful when the change is visual. -->

* Install and connect Jetpack. Purchase a plan that bundles Akismet. Ensure the "Akismet Anti-Spam" menu is present, and that you can successfully visit `/wp-admin/admin.php?page=akismet-key-config`.
* Install and activate Jetpack Backup. Ensure that only one Anti-Spam menu is present.

pull_request.title: Fix: wrong applied styles on Multiple checkbox in Contact From block
pull_request.body: Fixes https://github.com/Automattic/jetpack/issues/31397 ## Proposed changes: This PR should fix wrongly applied styles. In the current state, we are applying `opacity` and other styles on all `span` elements, while we should only apply them on "(required)" line. Note: Even though issue states about Tazza theme, issue persists on all themes. ### Other information: This issue is a bit odd, as it seems that Styles used here are from `deprecated` Forms module, while the code used is from the new package. I don't think we should iterate on this within this Fix, but, it would be resolved when we fully remove old Forms module. cc @jeherve - [ ] Have you written new tests for your changes, if applicable? - [ ] Have you checked the E2E test CI results, and verified that your changes do not break them? - [ ] Have you tested your changes on WordPress.com, if applicable (if so, you'll see a generated comment below with a script to run)? ## Jetpack product discussion ## Does this pull request change what data or activity we track or use? ## Testing instructions: * Download the branch locally and run `jetpack build plugins/jetpack` * Work with your JT or other jetpack setup environment * Create a new post and add Jetpack Form to it * Add a Multiple Choice (Checkbox) field * In block editor change the Option Text color * Save and check out the Post and verify that the styles the same as in Edit mode (see original issue for context on how it was before)

In the current state, we are applying `opacity` and other styles on all `span` elements, while we should only apply them on "(required)" line. Note: Even though issue states about Tazza theme, issue persists on all themes. ### Other information: This issue is a bit odd, as it seems that Styles used here are from `deprecated` Forms module, while the code used is from the new package. I don't think we should iterate on this within this Fix, but, it would be resolved when we fully remove old Forms module. cc @jeherve - [ ] Have you written new tests for your changes, if applicable? - [ ] Have you checked the E2E test CI results, and verified that your changes do not break them? - [ ] Have you tested your changes on WordPress.com, if applicable (if so, you'll see a generated comment below with a script to run)? ## Jetpack product discussion ## Does this pull request change what data or activity we track or use? ## Testing instructions: * Download the branch locally and run `jetpack build plugins/jetpack` * Work with your JT or other jetpack setup environment * Create a new post and add Jetpack Form to it * Add a Multiple Choice (Checkbox) field * In block editor change the Option Text color * Save and check out the Post and verify that the styles the same as in Edit mode (see original issue for context on how it was before)

pull_request.title: Introduce VideoPress content gating
pull_request.body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->
<!-- Would you like this feature to be tested by Beta testers?
Please add testing instructions to projects/plugins/jetpack/to-test.md in a new commit as part of your PR. -->
<!-- a12s: If you have an expected version that you're aiming for the PR to add, please use the Milestone field to communicate it. If you leave it blank, that indicates there isn't a preference. -->

Fixes https://github.com/Automattic/greenhouse/issues/1808

## Proposed changes:
<!--- Explain what functional changes your PR includes -->
* Alters the behavior of private videos when embedded within blocks/posts that restrict content to subscribers.
* Introduces a way for blocks to control the unauthorized message the video player will display.
* The video iframe and it's files will not be available if a logged in user has no paid subscription, even if logged in.

### Other information:

- [ ] Have you written new tests for your changes, if applicable?
- [ ] Have you checked the E2E test CI results, and verified that your changes do not break them?
- [ ] Have you tested your changes on WordPress.com, if applicable (if so, you'll see a generated comment below with a script to run)?

## Jetpack product discussion

pxWta-1VK-p2

## Does this pull request change what data or activity we track or use?
no

## Testing instructions:
<!-- If you were reviewing this PR, how would you like the instructions to be presented? -->
<!-- Please include detailed testing steps, explaining how to test your change. -->
<!-- Bear in mind that context you working on is not obvious for everyone.  -->
<!-- Adding "simple" configuration steps will help reviewers to get to your PR as quickly as possible. -->
<!-- "Before / After" screenshots can also be very helpful when the change is visual. -->

* You need the Jetpack plugin to test this, as all Earn blocks are Jetpack-plugin-only.
* Do a full rebuild: `pnpm jetpack build plugins/jetpack --deps`
* Refer to pxWta-1VK-p2 on what to sandbox and what not.
* You will need to setup paid subscriptions and paid newsletter subscriptions.
* You will need 1 simple user, 1 newsletter sub user and 1 paid sub user.
* You will need to upgrade to a plan that includes more than one VideoPress videos. (because you are sandboxing store, you might need to do that again)
* On your test site, ensure you can access the paid content block.
* If you haven't, connect to stripe. If you sandboxed store, you can choose to use a "test" connection when on stripe's site.
* You are connected to test stripe now.

### Paid content block

* Go ahead and create a new post and add a "Paid Content" block.
* Assign a subscription plan.
* On the Subscriber view, create a VideoPress block and upload a video. Set privacy to private.
* Save.
* View as admin/editor. You can see the video.
* Try to view as a non-paid subscriber. You should not be able to view.
* View as a paid subscriber. You can view content and video.

### Newsletter

* Enable Newsletters (Jetpack -> Settings -> Newsletters). Create a newsletter subscription.
* Create a new post and set access to paid subscribers only.
* Add a videopress video, set to private. Save and publish.
* View as non-subscriber. You cant access anything.
* View as subscriber. You can see the video.

### Paywall

* Enable Newsletters (Jetpack -> Settings -> Newsletters). Create a newsletter subscription.
* Create post and upload a Video. Set it to public.
* Add a paywall block and upload another video. Set it to private.
* Publish post.
* View as guest and subscriber. You only see the video if a subscriber.

* You will need to setup paid subscriptions and paid newsletter subscriptions.
* You will need 1 simple user, 1 newsletter sub user and 1 paid sub user.
* You will need to upgrade to a plan that includes more than one VideoPress videos. (because you are sandboxing store, you might need to do that again)
* On your test site, ensure you can access the paid content block.
* If you haven't, connect to stripe. If you sandboxed store, you can choose to use a "test" connection when on stripe's site.
* You are connected to test stripe now.

### Paid content block

* Go ahead and create a new post and add a "Paid Content" block.
* Assign a subscription plan.
* On the Subscriber view, create a VideoPress block and upload a video. Set privacy to private.
* Save.
* View as admin/editor. You can see the video.
* Try to view as a non-paid subscriber. You should not be able to view.
* View as a paid subscriber. You can view content and video.

### Newsletter

* Enable Newsletters (Jetpack -> Settings -> Newsletters). Create a newsletter subscription.
* Create a new post and set access to paid subscribers only.
* Add a videopress video, set to private. Save and publish.
* View as non-subscriber. You cant access anything.
* View as subscriber. You can see the video.

### Paywall

* Enable Newsletters (Jetpack -> Settings -> Newsletters). Create a newsletter subscription.
* Create post and upload a Video. Set it to public.
* Add a paywall block and upload another video. Set it to private.
* Publish post.
* View as guest and subscriber. You only see the video if a subscriber.

issue.title: Connection: add partner codes are added to connection URLs

labels.name: [Type] Bug
labels.description: When a feature is broken and / or not performing as intended

labels.name: [Status] Needs Review
labels.description: To request a review from Crew. Label will be renamed soon.

labels.name: [Plugin] Jetpack
labels.description: Issues about the Jetpack plugin. https://wordpress.org/plugins/jetpack/

issue.body:
## Proposed changes:

This PR changes the way the Partner codes were added when connecting a site to a WordPress.com account, so this can work with standalone plugins.

This was previously only done in the Jetpack plugin, in 2 ways:

- The Partner package is initialized on plugins_loaded in the main Jetpack class.
- In Jetpack's `build_authorize_url` method we have a `jetpack_build_authorize_url` filter that is leveraged by the Partner package.

Standalone plugins, on the other hand, do not use `Jetpack::build_authorize_url()`. This method is obviously only available in the Jetpack plugin, and so standalone plugins do not have that `jetpack_build_authorize_url` filter.

We fix this discrepancy in this PR:

- We now initialize the Partner package in the connection package.
- We add the `jetpack_build_authorize_url` filter to the connection package's `get_authorization_url` method, so the partner codes can be added to all URLs.
- We stop initializing the Partner package in the Jetpack plugin, since it is now done in the connection package.

> **Note**
> This does not add the Partner package as a new dependency for the Connection package, since the Partner package already declares the connection package as a dependency.

### Other information:

- [ ] Have you written new tests for your changes, if applicable?
- [ ] Have you checked the E2E test CI results, and verified that your changes do not break them?
- [ ] Have you tested your changes on WordPress.com, if applicable (if so, you'll see a generated comment below with a script to run)?

## Jetpack product discussion

* pbtFPC-6ha-p2

## Does this pull request change what data or activity we track or use?

* No

## Testing instructions:

There may be an easier way to test this, but here is how I went about it.

**You will want to test the process in both the Jetpack plugin and a standalone plugin like Jetpack Protect**.

* On a brand new site,
* Via WP CLI, set up an affiliate code and a subsiadiary code:
    * `wp option update jetpack_partner_subsidiary_id jeremy`
    * `wp option update jetpack_affiliate_code 123456`
* Install a Jetpack plugin (Jetpack or something else).
* Open your browser's network tools
* Filter for `jetpack.wordpress.com` requests
* Start the connection process
* Check the arguments added to the jetpack.wordpress.com request
    * It should include both an `aff` and a `subsidiaryId` argument, using the values defined above.

labels.name: [Type] Bug
labels.description: When a feature is broken and / or not performing as intended

labels.name: [Status] Needs Review
labels.description: To request a review from Crew. Label will be renamed soon.

labels.name: [Plugin] Jetpack
labels.description: Issues about the Jetpack plugin. https://wordpress.org/plugins/jetpack/

issue.body:
## Proposed changes:

This PR changes the way the Partner codes were added when connecting a site to a WordPress.com account, so this can work with standalone plugins.

This was previously only done in the Jetpack plugin, in 2 ways:

- The Partner package is initialized on plugins_loaded in the main Jetpack class.
- In Jetpack's `build_authorize_url` method we have a `jetpack_build_authorize_url` filter that is leveraged by the Partner package.

Standalone plugins, on the other hand, do not use `Jetpack::build_authorize_url()`. This method is obviously only available in the Jetpack plugin, and so standalone plugins do not have that `jetpack_build_authorize_url` filter.

We fix this discrepancy in this PR:

- We now initialize the Partner package in the connection package.
- We add the `jetpack_build_authorize_url` filter to the connection package's `get_authorization_url` method, so the partner codes can be added to all URLs.
- We stop initializing the Partner package in the Jetpack plugin, since it is now done in the connection package.

> **Note**
> This does not add the Partner package as a new dependency for the Connection package, since the Partner package already declares the connection package as a dependency.

### Other information:

- [ ] Have you written new tests for your changes, if applicable?
- [ ] Have you checked the E2E test CI results, and verified that your changes do not break them?
- [ ] Have you tested your changes on WordPress.com, if applicable (if so, you'll see a generated comment below with a script to run)?

## Jetpack product discussion

* pbtFPC-6ha-p2

## Does this pull request change what data or activity we track or use?

* No

## Testing instructions:

There may be an easier way to test this, but here is how I went about it.

**You will want to test the process in both the Jetpack plugin and a standalone plugin like Jetpack Protect**.

* On a brand new site,
* Via WP CLI, set up an affiliate code and a subsiadiary code:
    * `wp option update jetpack_partner_subsidiary_id jeremy`
    * `wp option update jetpack_affiliate_code 123456`
* Install a Jetpack plugin (Jetpack or something else).
* Open your browser's network tools
* Filter for `jetpack.wordpress.com` requests
* Start the connection process
* Check the arguments added to the jetpack.wordpress.com request
    * It should include both an `aff` and a `subsidiaryId` argument, using the values defined above.

pull_request.title: Introduce VideoPress content gating
pull_request.body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->
<!-- Would you like this feature to be tested by Beta testers?
Please add testing instructions to projects/plugins/jetpack/to-test.md in a new commit as part of your PR. -->
<!-- a12s: If you have an expected version that you're aiming for the PR to add, please use the Milestone field to communicate it. If you leave it blank, that indicates there isn't a preference. -->

Fixes https://github.com/Automattic/greenhouse/issues/1808

## Proposed changes:
<!--- Explain what functional changes your PR includes -->
* Alters the behavior of private videos when embedded within blocks/posts that restrict content to subscribers.
* Introduces a way for blocks to control the unauthorized message the video player will display.
* The video iframe and it's files will not be available if a logged in user has no paid subscription, even if logged in.

### Other information:

- [ ] Have you written new tests for your changes, if applicable?
- [ ] Have you checked the E2E test CI results, and verified that your changes do not break them?
- [ ] Have you tested your changes on WordPress.com, if applicable (if so, you'll see a generated comment below with a script to run)?

## Jetpack product discussion

pxWta-1VK-p2

## Does this pull request change what data or activity we track or use?
no

## Testing instructions:
<!-- If you were reviewing this PR, how would you like the instructions to be presented? -->
<!-- Please include detailed testing steps, explaining how to test your change. -->
<!-- Bear in mind that context you working on is not obvious for everyone.  -->
<!-- Adding "simple" configuration steps will help reviewers to get to your PR as quickly as possible. -->
<!-- "Before / After" screenshots can also be very helpful when the change is visual. -->

* You need the Jetpack plugin to test this, as all Earn blocks are Jetpack-plugin-only.
* Do a full rebuild: `pnpm jetpack build plugins/jetpack --deps`
* Refer to pxWta-1VK-p2 on what to sandbox and what not.
* You will need to setup paid subscriptions and paid newsletter subscriptions.
* You will need 1 simple user, 1 newsletter sub user and 1 paid sub user.
* You will need to upgrade to a plan that includes more than one VideoPress videos. (because you are sandboxing store, you might need to do that again)
* On your test site, ensure you can access the paid content block.
* If you haven't, connect to stripe. If you sandboxed store, you can choose to use a "test" connection when on stripe's site.
* You are connected to test stripe now.

### Paid content block

* Go ahead and create a new post and add a "Paid Content" block.
* Assign a subscription plan.
* On the Subscriber view, create a VideoPress block and upload a video. Set privacy to private.
* Save.
* View as admin/editor. You can see the video.
* Try to view as a non-paid subscriber. You should not be able to view.
* View as a paid subscriber. You can view content and video.

### Newsletter

* Enable Newsletters (Jetpack -> Settings -> Newsletters). Create a newsletter subscription.
* Create a new post and set access to paid subscribers only.
* Add a videopress video, set to private. Save and publish.
* View as non-subscriber. You cant access anything.
* View as subscriber. You can see the video.

### Paywall

* Enable Newsletters (Jetpack -> Settings -> Newsletters). Create a newsletter subscription.
* Create post and upload a Video. Set it to public.
* Add a paywall block and upload another video. Set it to private.
* Publish post.
* View as guest and subscriber. You only see the video if a subscriber.
